so inspired by dr davidson & dr  - role models listening to patients, being brave & innovative in trying to meet urgent need, evaluating & improving programs
program is not just about the dextroamphetamine medication, but about more comprehensive primary care & services, connection
all patients find dextroamphetamine substitution prescribing helpful, keeping engaged in primary care. one found very helpful for meth use/cravings but not for cocaine use/cravings
in intake surveys, this group in fredericton have high adverse childhood experiences (aces) scores & also high resiliency scores - people facing challenges with incredible survival skills
participants in program are highly motivated to change, and find dextroamphetamine prescribing supportive and helping enhance confidence - many finding multiple substances difficult to manage
average doses 57.7mg dextroamphetamine daily, every participant has completed titration & wants to stay on therapy
monitoring involved daily check in with supportive pharmacist team-member, and weekly or biweekly md clinic visits. titrated individually

overall response from csam2019 audience at “safer supply” sessions seems to be appreciation of crisis & bravery/creative approaches needed to save lives. questions raised about best approach, potential harms & evaluation raised within this context of respect & recogntion of need

audience question about if “safer supply” prescribing is offered to people who have not tried methadone or bupe it is offered to patients at extreme risk who are not open to methadone/bupe & shared decision that this could help keep them alive, would be unethical to withhold
meant to say this is all at csam2019 in halifax!
average injectable dose has increased over time (perhaps in part due to increasing tolerances related to fentanyl in community) but some clients stopped injecting & switch to fully oral treatment
compare this to real world data on oral methadone & buprenorphine retention at 12 months, which may be between 10-20%
retention at 12 months has been excellent - greater than 80%
29 clients in the program- 100% experiencing homelessness at intake, 100% with psychiatric dx, many with hiv & other medical comorbidities

ottawa innner city health managed opioid program is a residential program where clients can inject liquid hydromorphone up to 7 times per day, with oral oat in the background to minimize withdrawal between doses

people who inject drugs & experience unstable housing in ottawa face extreme risk of overdose death & other drug related harms - many overdosing multiple times per day, hard to stay on traditional oat, interrupted when incarcerated

multiple rcts show benefit of prescribed injectable heroin (diacetylmorphine) on treatment outcomes, but access is restricted salome trial showed injectable hydromorphone (which is accessible) to be noninferior:
oral oat with methadone, buprenorphine/naloxone, or slow release oral morphine works well & helps save many lives - but doesn’t work for everyone
. presenting on ottawa inner city health’s experience with hydromorphone injectable opioid agonist therapy (ioat)
cpso has visited the program as an audit, and explained while it is not their role to approve or disapprove of specific programs, were satisfied & believed the program be doing lifesaving work
data shared from initial evaluation (undergoing peer review) shows positive outcomes for reducing fentanyl use, homelessness, and hiv viremia

offered immediate release hydromorphone tablets rather than controlled release b/c of previous research showing increased risk of bacterial infections with contin formulations https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0219777 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/21370963/
patients start on 6-8 tabs of hydromorphone 8mg per day, dispensed all at once each day. offered 24-hour sustained release oral morphine at the same time guidance documents & protocols here:
“safer supply” prescribing currently offered to patients identified at high risk of death & other drug related harms, and who previously tried other forms of treatment
program initially began after observing patients with endocarditis/epidural abscess did extremely well when discharged from hospital with daily dispensed hydromorphone tablets
. invites prescribers to reconceptualize safer injecting practices to include sterile injecting equipment, safer technique, and also safer drugs themselves
highlighting accomplishments of scaling up existing harm reduction approaches on preventing overdose deaths - but how to reach those still at highest risk?

. invites prescribers to re-consider “safer use” from clean rigs & injecting practices to include a safer supply of the drugs themselves
